highlights.text: Moreover, such systems can adversely impactfundamental rights, if not developed and used properly.    Therefore, the proposed AI Act classifies certain AI systems e.g. for making decisions onpromotions or monitoring and evaluating performance and behaviour of persons, includingfor emotion recognition at the workplace, as high-risk systems. Under the proposed AI Act,such high-risk systems need to comply with requirements and to undergo a conformityassessment. The proposal also provides that emotion

objective will also be considered in the ongoingreview of the Workplace and Display Screen Directives Council Directive 89/654/EEC andCouncil Directive 90/270/EEC.    On 21 April 2021, the Commission proposed the first-ever legal framework on AI the AIAct 1 , as a follow-up to the 2020 White Paper 2 . The proposed rules follow a risk-basedapproach to the placing on the market and use of AI systems in the EU.    The use of AI in the field of employment, in particular tools for recruitment and to monitor

emotion recognition and biometric categorisationsystems will always be subject to specific transparency obligations, so that employees arealways aware when such systems are used.    The proposed AI Act is currently being discussed with the European Parliament and theCouncil. The co-legislators may suggest possible modifications to the proposal.    1    COM2021 206 final.    2    COM2020 65 final.

topics: Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union

highlights.text: Fundamental Rights, in particular the rights to data protection, privacy, nondiscrimination,freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. The AI Act proposalcomplements the existing legal framework on data protection, anti-discrimination andconsumer protection, thus enhancing the high level of protection of fundamental rights andfreedoms in the Union.    The AI Act proposal bans real-time remote biometric identification systems in publiclyaccessible spaces for the purpose of law enforcement, subject

ENE-003888/2021Answer given by Mr Bretonon behalf of the European Commission5.11.2021    The Commission adopted on 21 April 2021 a proposal for a Regulation 1 laying downharmonised rules on Artificial Intelligence the AI Act that puts forward proportionate andflexible rules to address the specific risks posed by high-risk AI systems. In drawing up thoserules, the Commission took into account comments from more than 1250 stakeholders.    The use of automated recognition

stakeholders. Ingeneral, stakeholders welcomed the Commissions effort to ensure trustworthy use of AI.Non-governmental organisations, inter alia, called for a more restrictive approach on the useof remote biometric identification systems.    The proposed AI Act is now subject to negotiations with Member States in Council and theEuropean Parliament within the ordinary legislative procedure.    1    COM2021 206 final.    2    The feedback can be found under: https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/

highlights.text: current threatsand to anticipate future risks and opportunities. In April, the Commission made a proposal forharmonised rules the AI Act 64 which aims to turn Europe into the global hub fortrustworthy AI. An important part of these proposals focuses on high-risk AI systems thatpose significant risks to the health and safety or fundamental rights of individuals. The AIAct would provide that the use of real-time remote biometric identification in publiclyaccessible spaces for the purpose of law enforcement

enforcement is in principle prohibited, with tightlyframed exceptions. These kinds of high-risk systems must comply with a set of horizontalmandatory requirements for trustworthy AI, including traceability, transparency and humanoversight, and accuracy. The AI Act would have a significant impact in the area of lawenforcement and border controls. It seeks to create a balanced framework of oversightthroughout the life-cycle of high-risk systems used by law enforcement authorities, and putsin place a set of safeguards

EU programmes and policies    In addition to the recent proposal of a European AI Act, briefly described above, a number of other EUprogrammes and policies have to be mentioned. A digital transformation which contributes to asustainable, climate-neutral and resource-efficient economy is a key objective of the Commissionsdigital strategy
